metadata.title: From scratch to search: playing with your data (Elasticsearch Ingest Pipelines) | by Stanislav Prihoda 🔥 | Towards Data Science
metadata.h1: From scratch to search: playing with your data (Elasticsearch Ingest Pipelines)
metadata.description: In this article I would like to quickly go through one interesting feature (of many) offered by Elasticsearch that I tend to use also in production setups which are the Ingest Pipelines. This feature…

all_paragraphs: In this article I would like to quickly go through one interesting feature (of many) offered by Elasticsearch that I tend to use also in production setups which are the Ingest Pipelines. This feature allows to pre-process documents before the actual document indexing happens. Sounds interesting, what for…

This can be useful in many ways but I can see two main reasons. Firstly, when you are more on the (big) data analytics/processing side, your priorities (and mandate) are likely not set to involve active changing of the source systems. So you have to deal with the raw data as they come and preprocess them to fit your data needs. Secondly, even if you intend to change the producers you A) may not have all under direct control (eg. due to some organisational aspects, their legacy nature eg.) and/or B) still need to be prepared that the change may take quite a while (eg. think of tens/hundreds of microservices you want to upgrade on a new version of the your shared logging library etc.).
For these cases you can call to service the ingest pipelines.

The ingest pipelines are newer player in the field of data parsing and transformations long occupied by Logstash. Ingest pipelines are actually not a full replacement of Logstash. But the consideration with Logstash is that it inevitably brings another sw component to your architecture thus making it more complicated to operate. This is not the case for the ingest pipelines as these are executed directly by any (or all) of the regular Elasticsearch nodes in your cluster. The node just needs to be of the type of Ingest node (which is by default) so you don’t even need to mess with the configuration when you want to start using them.

Generally the pipelines are defined via a simple JSON document that contains an array of processors which represent an ordered set of steps that are applied and executed on all incoming documents. Actual processors come in various flavours so I highly recommend to crawl through their list in the docs to get familiar.
Processors share some things in common. These are:

Enough of theory, let’s spin up a simple (single node) cluster in Docker on our local machine and try out a first pipeline definition. Note: if you need more info on the docker part find it in my previous article. Let’s do also an instance of Kibana to have a simple GUI for review.
When you run the script above and wait couple of minutes your temporary elastic stack should spin up and be ready for our pipeline tests (with Kibana running on http://localhost:5601/).
To test it we’ll start small and create a pipeline that will:
Now let’s create an index that will use this pipeline as its default ingest pipeline.
Finally let’s index a dummy document that will be processed by this pipeline.
Now we can take a look on the document in Kibana. Note: don’t forget to create an index pattern. We can see the transformations in place.
No let’s try two things and to be effective let’s use them both in one processor :)
Both of these use a Painless scripting language (which is based on Groovy). Read the painless guide for more info. Nevertheless important is that:
Simple example: we can use this to index only a part (substring) of the original text if rest is useless for our purposes. So just replace the pipeline…
… and index a new document.

If you are processing data that are structured in some well-defined format (but not extracted in individual fields) you can try out Dissect Processor. Just describe the pattern with individual fields for extraction enclosed in curly braces with percent sign%{my_field}.
We can use this processor to parse structured field out of default NGINX log line format (combined/main) which has following structure.
For more info on NGINX logging see docs for the logging module ngx_http_log_module. We can also use the Date Processor to extract the @timestamp as the original value defaults to non-standard format.
Let's put it in new pipeline.
Now you can POST a log line in the message field and have it extracted. Note that you can override the default pipeline in our index with the new one in query string.
Refresh your index pattern and take a look in Kibana.
If you want to try it in action just spin up nginx docker container and find your logs in /var/log/nginx.
You can use similar processors for differently formatted contents such as CSV Processor (to extracts fields from csv), KV Processor (to parse key=value pairs) or regex-based Grok Processor.
Last thing we'll use is the Enrich Processor that can be used to enrich your ingested document with data from another index. Cool right!
It has three prerequisites before you can use it in your pipeline:

Let’s extend the previous example and have a source index with known IP addresses (let’s just forget the fact we are now running on localhost :)) that we will check to append some data and see if the IP is not on a potential black-list.
First create the source index and one document (note: using refresh query param to be sure the index is immediately available for searching):
Next will create the Enrich policy. It's simple — just linking with our source index (that we created above), matching on the ip field and listing relevant fields.
We need to execute it to create the enrich index.

Now we can finally add the Enrich Processor to our previous nginx pipeline. We need to reference the enrich policy, the field we will be matching on (remote_addr that we extracted in a previous step), target field for the enrich data and max_matches (maximum number of matched documents to include). Add following to the processors …
Now just (re)POST the previous document (with the same nginx log line) and have the log content extracted and then enriched from our “ip info” index.

As a last thing I would like to point you towards additional concepts and features either of the ingest pipelines themself of useful in conjunction with them when you want to start using pipelines in your actual scenarios.

If you rotate your indexes (which you probably should when dealing with timeseries data, above tens of GBs in size etc.) and even more if you have these automated via index lifecycle management (which I tend to do) definitely recommended is to utilize the index templates. These help to formalize configuration (settings and mappings) for all indexes created from the index template.
From the pipelines perspective you can specify in the settings:
Before you include these just make sure your pipelines exist or you requests will fail.

Definitely useful (when you have your pipeline in place and need to perform some changes) is to test these via _simulate API. You can specify the new pipeline definition in the request body along with couple of test documents and get the results as if these were processed.

Make sure you handle eventual failures occurring during the execution of the pipeline. Do so by defining the on_failure block (consisting of some other processors) either at the level of a specific processor or of the pipeline as a whole.
Eg. pass the problematic document to a different index.

For the cases where you need a conditional execution (ie only if the field exists) make sure you handle the cases when the referenced field is missing or has an invalid value. You can do so either through ignore_missing attribute offered by some of the processors (Convert, Rename, Remove…) or in the if block.

Often when you discover ingest pipelines you already have loads of data in your existing indexes. To get this data processed by your new shiny pipeline just create a new index and use the reindex API to copy the data. To get the data processed either specify the pipeline in the index settings or in the reindex request body.
Note: be more cautions when reindexing with ILM.
We went through various features of the ingest pipelines and tested them out. Hopefully you liked the intro and you can see some potential in your scenarios.
